concept.label: soup
concept.definition: Soup is a primarily liquid food, generally served warm or hot (but may be cool or cold), that is made by combining ingredients of meat or vegetables with stock, milk, or water. Hot soups are additionally characterized by boiling solid ingredients in liquids in a pot until the flavors are extracted, forming a broth. Soups are similar to stews, and in some cases there may not be a clear distinction between the two; however, soups generally have more liquid (broth) than stews.In traditional French cuisine, soups are classified into two main groups: clear soups and thick soups. The established French classifications of clear soups are bouillon and consommé. Thick soups are classified depending upon the type of thickening agent used: purées are vegetable soups thickened with starch; bisques are made from puréed shellfish or vegetables thickened with cream; cream soups may be thickened with béchamel sauce; and veloutés are thickened with eggs, butter, and cream. Other ingredients commonly used to thicken soups and broths include  rice, lentils, flour, and grains; many popular soups also include pumpkin, carrots, potatoes, pig's trotters and bird's nests.Other types of soup include fruit soups, dessert soups, pulse soups like split pea, cold soups and other styles.

data.name: Cucumber soup
data.description:
Cucumber soup is a traditional Polish and Lithuanian soup (Polish: Zupa ogórkowa, [zupa ɔɡurkɔva]). It is  made from sour, salted cucumbers and potato. Occasionally rice is substituted for the potatoes.
Cucumber soup is also any soup using cucumbers as a primary ingredient, and is present in various cuisines. The two major varieties are fresh cucumber soup and pickled cucumber soup.
A similar soup is also common in Russia and Ukraine, where it is known as rassolnik. There is another cucumber based soup known as tarator in Bulgaria, which is served cold.
data.rationale: Cucumber soup fits the definition of soup as it is a primarily liquid food that is made by combining ingredients of cucumbers and potatoes with water or stock. It can be served warm or cold, depending on the variety. The definition also mentions that soups can be classified into different types based on the thickening agent used, and in the case of cucumber soup, potatoes or rice can serve as the thickening agent. Furthermore, the definition mentions that soups can include vegetables, which cucumbers are. Therefore, based on the provided definition, cucumber soup can be classified as a soup.

data.name: Soup joumou
data.description:
Soup joumou (; French: soupe au giraumon) is a soup native to Haitian cuisine. In 2021, soup joumou was added to the UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage List.
The soup is traditionally cooked with winter squashes such as the turban squash. The squash slices are simmered in a saucepan along with pieces of beef and soup bones, potato, and vegetables such as malanga, leeks, celery, radishes, carrots, green cabbage, habanero pepper and onions. The squash is then puréed, usually in a food processor, with water and the purée is returned to the saucepan. Salt and seasoning along with lime juice, garlic, parsley and other herbs and spices are then added. Some Haitians add thin pasta such as vermicelli and macaroni and a small amount of butter or oil. The soup is always served hot and is usually accompanied with sliced bread which is dipped in the soup.
data.rationale: Soup joumou fits the definition of a soup as it is a primarily liquid food that is made by combining ingredients of meat and vegetables with water. The process of making Soup joumou involves boiling solid ingredients in liquids in a pot until the flavors are extracted, forming a broth, which is characteristic of hot soups. The soup is thickened with the purée of squash, which aligns with the classification of thick soups that are thickened with starch. The soup also includes other ingredients commonly used to thicken soups such as potatoes and vegetables. Furthermore, Soup joumou is served hot, which is typical of most soups. Therefore, based on the provided definition, Soup joumou can be classified as a soup.

data.name: Bissara
data.description:
Bissara, bessara, besarah and tamarakt (Arabic: بصارة) is a dish in Egyptian cuisine and Moroccan cuisine. The dish contains split fava beans, onions, garlic, fresh aromatic herbs and spices. All ingredients are slowly cooked and then blended together to yield a creamy and fragrant dip or side dish. 
In ancient Jewish cuisine, a similar dish, known as "mikpah ful" in rabbinic literature, was commonly consumed.
data.rationale: Bissara fits the definition of a soup because it is a primarily liquid food that is made by combining ingredients of split fava beans, onions, garlic, fresh aromatic herbs and spices with water or stock. These ingredients are slowly cooked until the flavors are extracted, forming a broth, which aligns with the process of making hot soups. Furthermore, Bissara is then blended together to yield a creamy dish, which suggests that it could be classified as a thick soup, specifically a purée, as it is a vegetable soup thickened with starch from the fava beans. Therefore, based on the provided definition, Bissara can be considered a soup.

data.name: Chowder
data.description: Chowder is a thick  soup prepared with milk or cream, a roux, and seafood or vegetables. Oyster crackers or saltines may accompany chowders as a side item, and cracker pieces may be dropped atop the dish. New England clam chowder is typically made with chopped clams and diced potatoes, in a mixed cream and milk base, often with a small amount of butter. Other common chowders include seafood chowder, which often consists of fish, clams, and other types of shellfish; lamb or veal chowder made with barley; corn chowder, which uses corn instead of clams; various fish chowders; and potato chowder, which is often made with cheese. Fish, corn, and clam chowders are popular in North America, especially New England and Atlantic Canada.
data.rationale:
The definition of soup provided states that it is a primarily liquid food that is made by combining ingredients of meat or vegetables with stock, milk, or water. It can be served warm or hot and is characterized by boiling solid ingredients in liquids in a pot until the flavors are extracted, forming a broth. Soups can be classified into two main groups: clear soups and thick soups. Thick soups are classified depending upon the type of thickening agent used, which can include starch, cream, béchamel sauce, eggs, butter, and cream. 

The entity Chowder is described as a thick soup prepared with milk or cream, a roux, and seafood or vegetables. This description aligns with the definition of soup as it is a primarily liquid food made by combining ingredients with milk or cream, which is a type of stock. It is also characterized as a thick soup, which is a classification of soup according to the definition. Therefore, based on the provided definition of soup, Chowder can be classified as a type of soup.

data.name: Buttermilk koldskål
data.description:
Buttermilk koldskål (Danish: kærnemælkskoldskål, often simply koldskål – literally cold bowl) is a sweet cold dairy beverage or dessert eaten in Denmark.
Koldskål is made with buttermilk and other varying ingredients: eggs, sugar, cream and/or other dairy products, vanilla, and sometimes lemon. The dish arose when buttermilk became commonly available in Denmark in the early 1900s and was eaten chilled most days during the summer as a dessert or snack. Since 1979, there have been ready-made varieties on the Danish market, originally from Esbjerg Dairy, but now from a range of dairies, including Arla.
The earliest mentions of koldskål are from the 18th century, where the term was used to describe a sweet beer-based gruel, however this dish is not commonly eaten any more. It was not until the 19th century that recipes for buttermilk-based koldskål appeared, and it took until the 20th century for the dish to become a mainstay in Danish homes.Traditionally, buttermilk koldskål is served with dry, crispy biscuits such as kammerjunker or tvebakker. Sometimes sliced strawberries or bananas are added.
Like most activities in Denmark, the consumption of koldskål is highly dependent on the weather, and a couple of weeks of warm weather can double the demand for ready-made koldskål. In 2013, Arla sold 3.8 million litres of koldskål in the month of July alone (about 2/3 litres per Dane).
data.rationale: Buttermilk koldskål can be considered a soup based on the given definition. Soup is described as a primarily liquid food that can be served cool or cold, and is made by combining ingredients. Buttermilk koldskål is a cold dairy beverage or dessert that combines buttermilk with other ingredients such as eggs, sugar, cream, vanilla, and sometimes lemon. This aligns with the definition of soup as a liquid food made by combining ingredients. Furthermore, the definition of soup includes dessert soups and cold soups as types of soup, which further supports the classification of Buttermilk koldskål as a soup.

data.name: Menudo (soup)
data.description: In Mexican cuisine, Menudo, also known as pancita ([little] gut or [little] stomach) or mole de panza ("stomach sauce"), is a traditional Mexican soup, made with cow's stomach (tripe) in broth with a red chili pepper base. Hominy, lime, onions, and oregano are used to season the broth. It differs from the Filipino dish of the same name, in that the latter does not use tripe or a chili sauce.
data.rationale: Menudo fits the definition of a soup as it is a primarily liquid food that is made by combining ingredients of meat, in this case cow's stomach (tripe), with a broth base. The broth is seasoned with hominy, lime, onions, and oregano. This process aligns with the description of hot soups being characterized by boiling solid ingredients in liquids in a pot until the flavors are extracted, forming a broth. Furthermore, Menudo is a traditional Mexican dish, which aligns with the concept that soups can come from various culinary traditions. Therefore, based on the provided definition, Menudo can be classified as a soup.

data.name: Tomato soup
data.description: Tomato soup is a soup with tomatoes as the primary ingredient. It can be served hot or cold, and may be made in a variety of ways.  It may be smooth in texture, and there are also recipes that include chunks of tomato, cream, chicken or vegetable stock, vermicelli, chunks of other vegetables and meatballs. Many companies have their own versions of tomato soup which all vary in taste, portions and ingredients.
data.rationale: The definition of soup provided states that it is a primarily liquid food that is made by combining ingredients of meat or vegetables with stock, milk, or water. It can be served warm or hot, but may also be cool or cold. The description of Tomato soup fits this definition perfectly. Tomato soup is described as a soup with tomatoes as the primary ingredient, which aligns with the soup definition of combining vegetables with stock, milk, or water. It is also mentioned that Tomato soup can be served hot or cold, which is consistent with the general characteristics of soup. Furthermore, the description of Tomato soup includes variations that involve adding other ingredients such as cream, chicken or vegetable stock, vermicelli, chunks of other vegetables and meatballs, which is also in line with the definition of soup that involves boiling solid ingredients in liquids until the flavors are extracted. Therefore, based on the provided definition of soup, it can be argued that Tomato soup is a type of soup.

data.name: Rumford's Soup
data.description: Rumford's Soup (Rumfordsche Suppe, also called economy soup) was an early effort in scientific nutrition. It was invented by Benjamin Thompson, Reichsgraf von Rumford, circa 1800 and consumed in Munich and greater Bavaria, where he was employed as an advisor to Charles Theodore, Elector of Bavaria. It was used as a ration for the poor, for Bavarian workhouses and military workhouses, and prisoners. Count Rumford has been credited in many instances for "establishing the first real soup kitchen."As a reformatory measure, the Bavarian government intended to institute workhouses  for those on welfare. Rumford's charge was to provide the cheapest possible ration that was still a high-calorie, nutritious food. The soup came to be well known among philanthropic-minded people throughout Germany at the time, and Rumford set up his soup kitchens in many German cities.Rumford's soup was a common base for inexpensive military rations in Central Europe for much of the nineteenth and twentieth century.
data.rationale: Rumford's Soup fits the definition of a soup as it is a primarily liquid food that was created by combining ingredients. It was served warm and was made by boiling solid ingredients in liquids in a pot until the flavors were extracted, forming a broth. This is evident from the fact that it was used as a ration for the poor, for Bavarian workhouses and military workhouses, and prisoners, suggesting that it was a substantial and nourishing food source. Furthermore, it was invented by Benjamin Thompson, who was known for his efforts in scientific nutrition, indicating that the soup was likely nutritious and balanced. The fact that it was served in soup kitchens also supports the assertion that Rumford's Soup is a soup.

data.name: Ohaw
data.description:
Ohaw or rur is a savory soup of the Ainu people of northern Japan, flavored with fish or animal bones. Kelp is also used to add flavor to the stock. Unlike the majority of the traditional Japanese soups, the Ainu do not use miso or soy sauce in their soups. The solid ingredients such as meat, fish, vegetables and/or wild edible plants are added to the stock.
The name is phonetically similar to a Russian fish soup called "Ukha". Considering ohaw is a soup of Ainu people (geographically located in Northern Japan, and parts of Russia), it is safe to assume that both words are of the same origin.
data.rationale: Ohaw fits the definition of a soup as it is a primarily liquid food that is made by combining ingredients of meat or fish with a stock. The process of making Ohaw involves flavoring the stock with fish or animal bones, similar to how hot soups are characterized by boiling solid ingredients in liquids until the flavors are extracted, forming a broth. Additionally, the solid ingredients such as meat, fish, vegetables and/or wild edible plants are added to the stock, which aligns with the general method of soup preparation. Therefore, based on the provided definition, Ohaw can be classified as a soup.

data.name: Flaki
data.description: Flaki or flaczki is a traditional Polish tripe stew. It is one of the many Polish soups, which represent an important part of Polish cuisine. Along with bigos, żurek, and pierogi, it is one of the most notable specialities in Polish cuisine. Its name is derived from its main ingredient: thin, cleaned strips of beef tripe (in Polish: flaki  - which can also be literally translated to "guts").
data.rationale: Flaki fits the definition of a soup as it is a primarily liquid food that is made by combining ingredients of meat, in this case, beef tripe, with stock. It is served warm and is part of the traditional Polish cuisine. The process of making Flaki likely involves boiling the beef tripe in liquids until the flavors are extracted, forming a broth, which aligns with the characteristics of hot soups as described in the definition. Therefore, based on the provided definition, Flaki can be classified as a soup.

data.name: Amatriciana sauce
data.description: Sugo all'amatriciana (Italian pronunciation: [ˈsuːɡo allamatriˈtʃaːna]), or alla matriciana (in Romanesco dialect), also known as salsa all'amatriciana, is a traditional Italian pasta sauce based on guanciale (cured pork cheek), pecorino romano cheese, tomato, and, in some variations, onion. Originating from the town of Amatrice (in the mountainous Province of Rieti of Lazio region), the amatriciana is one of the best known pasta sauces in present-day Roman and Italian cuisine. The Italian government has named it a traditional agro-alimentary product of Lazio and amatriciana tradizionale is registered as a Traditional Speciality Guaranteed in the EU and the UK.
data.rationale: Based on the provided definition, it would be difficult to argue that Amatriciana sauce is a soup. The definition of soup involves a primarily liquid food made by combining ingredients of meat or vegetables with stock, milk, or water, often characterized by boiling solid ingredients in liquids until the flavors are extracted. On the other hand, Amatriciana sauce is a traditional Italian pasta sauce based on guanciale, pecorino romano cheese, tomato, and sometimes onion. It does not mention the use of stock, milk, or water, nor does it mention boiling solid ingredients in a liquid to extract flavors. Therefore, based on the provided definitions, it would not be accurate to classify Amatriciana sauce as a soup.

data.name: Charentais melon
data.description:
A Charentais melon is a type of French cantaloupe, Cucumis melo var. cantalupensis.
It is a small variety of melon, around the size of a softball. It has flesh similar to most cantaloupes, but with a distinct and more intense aroma, and a more orangey hue. It originated in the Charentes region of France, and is most associated with the Provençal area around the town of Cavaillon.  Most true Charentais melons are grown in and around this region, and are almost exclusively available in France, owing to the fact that their thin skin and soft flesh does not do well in shipping. Hybrids of this variety are widely grown, they are generally crossed with North American cantaloupes for better shipping characteristics and larger size.
data.rationale: Based on the provided definition, it is not possible to argue that a Charentais melon is a soup. The definition of soup involves a primarily liquid food made by combining ingredients of meat or vegetables with stock, milk, or water, and often involves boiling these ingredients to extract flavors. A Charentais melon, on the other hand, is a type of fruit and is not prepared or consumed in the same way as a soup. It is not combined with other ingredients and boiled to create a broth or liquid food. Therefore, according to the given definition, a Charentais melon cannot be classified as a soup.

data.name: Tomate frito
data.description:
Tomate frito (Spanish for fried tomato) is a pureed tomato sauce with a hint of onion and garlic, that can be used as a base ingredient or enjoyed simply for its own flavour.  It is distinct from most tomato sauces because the tomatoes have been fried, and its ingredients include a small amount of vegetable oil. 
It is the most common tomato ingredient of Spanish cuisine other than fresh tomatoes, and is sold under many brand names. When made by first low frying garlic and onion pieces in oil with spices and then adding the tomato puree it is known as sofrito.
data.rationale: Tomate frito could potentially be considered a soup based on the definition provided. Soup is described as a primarily liquid food made by combining ingredients of meat or vegetables with stock, milk, or water. Tomate frito is a pureed tomato sauce with onion and garlic, which aligns with the ingredients typically found in soup. Additionally, soup can be served warm or hot, and Tomate frito is typically served warm. Furthermore, the definition of soup includes the process of boiling solid ingredients in liquids until the flavors are extracted, forming a broth. In the case of Tomate frito, the tomatoes, onion, and garlic are fried, which could be seen as a similar process of flavor extraction. Therefore, based on the provided definition of soup, one could argue that Tomate frito fits this description.

data.name: Goulash
data.description: Goulash (Hungarian: gulyás) is a soup or stew of meat and vegetables seasoned with paprika and other spices. Originating in Hungary, goulash is a common meal predominantly eaten in Central Europe but also in other parts of Europe. It is one of the national dishes of Hungary and a symbol of the country.Its origin may be traced back as far as the 10th century, to stews eaten by Hungarian shepherds. At that time, the cooked and flavored meat was dried with the help of the sun and packed into bags produced from sheep's stomachs, needing only water to make it into a meal. Earlier versions of goulash did not include paprika, as it was not introduced to Europe until the 16th century.
data.rationale: Goulash fits the definition of a soup because it is a primarily liquid food made by combining ingredients of meat and vegetables with water. The process of making goulash involves boiling these solid ingredients in liquid until the flavors are extracted, forming a broth, which is a characteristic of hot soups. Furthermore, goulash is seasoned with paprika and other spices, which aligns with the practice of flavoring soups. Although goulash can also be classified as a stew, the definition acknowledges that there may not always be a clear distinction between soups and stews. Therefore, based on the provided definition, goulash can be considered a type of soup.

data.name: Juven
data.description: Juven is a medical food that is manufactured by Abbott Laboratories and used to provide nutritional support under the care of a physician in individuals with muscle wasting due to AIDS or cancer, to promote wound healing following surgery or injury, or when otherwise recommended by a medical professional.  It is a powdered nutritional supplement that contains 3 grams of calcium β-hydroxy β-methylbutyrate, 14 grams of L-arginine, and 14 grams of L-glutamine per two daily servings.Juven has been shown to increase lean body mass during clinical trials in individuals with AIDS and cancer, but not rheumatoid cachexia. Clinical trials with Juven for AIDS have also demonstrated improvements in immune status, as measured by a reduced HIV viral load relative to controls and higher CD3+ and CD8+ cell counts. The efficacy of Juven for the treatment of cancer cachexia was also examined in a phase 3 clinical trial which found a strong trend (i.e., p=.08) for an improvement in lean body mass relative to controls; however, according to the authors of the trial itself and a systematic review that included it, the trial did not adequately test the ability of Juven to prevent or reverse the loss of lean body mass in individuals with cancer cachexia since the majority of participants did not complete the study. Further research involving the treatment of cancer cachexia with Juven over a period of several months is required to adequately determine treatment efficacy.
data.rationale: Based on the provided definition, it would be difficult to argue that Juven is a soup. The definition of soup involves it being a primarily liquid food, made by combining ingredients of meat or vegetables with stock, milk, or water, and often involves boiling these ingredients to extract flavors and create a broth. Juven, on the other hand, is described as a powdered nutritional supplement, which does not align with the characteristics of a soup. It is not made from meat or vegetables, nor is it boiled to extract flavors. It is intended for medical use to provide nutritional support, rather than being a food consumed for sustenance or pleasure. Therefore, based on the provided definitions, Juven does not meet the criteria to be classified as a soup.

data.name: Gado-gado
data.description: Gado-gado (Indonesian or Betawi) is an Indonesian salad of raw, slightly boiled, blanched or steamed vegetables and hard-boiled eggs, boiled potato, fried tofu and tempeh, and lontong (rice wrapped in a banana leaf), served with a peanut sauce dressing.In 2018, gado-gado was promoted as one of five national dishes of Indonesia; the others are soto, sate, nasi goreng, and rendang.
data.rationale: Based on the provided definition, it would be challenging to argue that Gado-gado is a soup. The definition of soup involves a primarily liquid food made by combining ingredients of meat or vegetables with stock, milk, or water, often characterized by boiling solid ingredients in liquids until the flavors are extracted. Gado-gado, on the other hand, is described as an Indonesian salad of raw, slightly boiled, blanched or steamed vegetables and hard-boiled eggs, boiled potato, fried tofu and tempeh, and lontong, served with a peanut sauce dressing. It does not involve a primarily liquid base, nor does it involve boiling ingredients in a liquid to extract flavors. Therefore, based on the provided definitions, Gado-gado does not fit the criteria to be classified as a soup.

data.name: Triphala
data.description: Triphala ("three fruits") is an Ayurvedic herbal rasayana formula consisting of equal parts of three myrobalans, taken without seed: Amalaki (Phyllanthus emblica), Bibhitaki (Terminalia bellirica), and Haritaki (Terminalia chebula). It contains vitamin C.
data.rationale: Based on the provided definition, it is not possible to argue that Triphala is a soup. The definition of soup involves a primarily liquid food made by combining ingredients of meat or vegetables with stock, milk, or water, and often involves boiling these ingredients to extract flavors. Triphala, on the other hand, is an Ayurvedic herbal formula consisting of three types of myrobalans. It does not fit into the categories of clear soups or thick soups as defined in the text, and it does not involve the process of boiling ingredients in a liquid to extract flavors. Therefore, based on the provided definition, Triphala cannot be classified as a soup.

data.name: Carcamusa
data.description:
Carcamusa is a traditional dish of Spanish cuisine and a speciality of Toledo, often served as a bar snack. It is made from pork and seasonal vegetables stewed with tomatoes and bay leaves. It is a dish best served hot, traditionally in a small earthenware dish accompanied by a few slices of bread. It may be also served with tomato, peas or beans spiced with hot chili pepper sauce.
Popular culture suggests its name arises from a pun.  Camush is usually game meat (often venison) but can also mean wrinkled, since the bar where it was invented was frequented by male customers of a certain age (the wrinklies or carcass) entertaining some younger girls for amusement (their muses).
data.rationale: Carcamusa could be considered a soup based on the definition provided. It is a dish made by combining ingredients of meat (pork) and vegetables with tomatoes, which could be seen as a form of stock or water. The ingredients are stewed together, which is a process similar to the boiling of solid ingredients in liquids described in the definition of soup. The dish is served hot, which aligns with the typical serving method for soup. However, it is also noted that soups generally have more liquid or broth than stews, and it is not clear from the description whether Carcamusa has a significant amount of liquid. Therefore, while it shares some characteristics with soup, without further information it may be more accurate to classify Carcamusa as a stew rather than a soup.

data.name: Bozbash
data.description: Bozbash (Azerbaijani: bozbaş; Persian: آبگوشت بزباش; Tat: guşto buzbaş) is an Iranian dish consisting of meat stew (also described as a soup) popular in Armenia, Azerbaijan and Iran.
data.rationale: Bozbash fits the definition of a soup as it is a primarily liquid food made by combining ingredients of meat with stock or water. It is described as a meat stew, which according to the definition, can be similar to soup with the main difference being the amount of liquid or broth. While the exact amount of liquid in Bozbash is not specified, the fact that it is also described as a soup suggests that it likely contains a substantial amount of broth, aligning it with the definition of soup. Therefore, based on the provided definition, Bozbash can be classified as a soup.

data.name: Tempeh
data.description:
Tempeh or tempe (; Javanese: ꦠꦺꦩ꧀ꦥꦺ, romanized: témpé, pronounced [tempe]) is a traditional Indonesian food made from fermented soybeans. It is made by a natural culturing and controlled fermentation process that binds soybeans into a cake form. A fungus, Rhizopus oligosporus or Rhizopus oryzae, is used in the fermentation process and is also known as tempeh starter. 

It is especially popular on the island of Java, where it is a staple source of protein. Like tofu, tempeh is made from soybeans, but it is a whole-soybean product with different nutritional characteristics and textural qualities. Tempeh's fermentation process and its retention of the whole bean give it a higher content of protein, dietary fiber, and vitamins. It has a firm texture and an earthy flavor, which becomes more pronounced as it ages.
data.rationale: Based on the provided definition and information, it is not possible to argue that Tempeh is a soup. The definition of soup involves a primarily liquid food made by combining ingredients of meat or vegetables with stock, milk, or water, and often involves boiling these ingredients to extract flavors. On the other hand, Tempeh is a solid food made from fermented soybeans, formed into a cake through a natural culturing and controlled fermentation process. It does not involve any of the preparation methods or characteristics associated with soup. Therefore, based on the given definitions, Tempeh cannot be classified as a soup.
